greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle read by rows: T(n,k) = sum of all squares of the parts k in all partitions of n, with n >= 1, 1 <= k <= n.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 1..200, flattened
example: For n = 4 the partitions of 4 are [4], [2, 2], [3, 1], [2, 1, 1], [1, 1, 1, 1], so the squares of the parts are respectively [16], [4, 4], [9, 1], [4, 1, 1], [1, 1, 1, 1]. The sum of the squares of the parts 1 is 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 = 7. The sum of the squares of the parts 2 is 4 + 4 + 4 = 12. The sum of the squares of the parts 3 is 9. The sum of the squares of the parts 4 is 16. So the fourth row of triangle is [7, 12, 9, 16].
maple: b:= proc(n, i) option remember; `if`(n=0 or i=1, 1+n*x, b(n, i-1)+
T:= n-> (p-> seq(coeff(p, x, i), i=1..n))(b(n$2)):
mathematica: T[n_] := Table[Coefficient[#, x, i], {i, 1, n}]&[b[n, n]];
Table[T[n], {n, 1, 14}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, May 22 2018, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
program: (PARI) row(n) = {v = vector(n); forpart(p=n, for(k=1, #p, v[p[k]] += p[k]^2;);); v;} \\ _Michel Marcus_, Mar 20 2018
xref: Both A180681 and A206561 have the same row sums as this triangle.
results.author: _Omar E. Pol_, Mar 19 2018
